best_practices: Choose appropriate topology for your workflow: mesh for research and collaboration, hierarchical for structured development, star for testing and centralized coordination, ring for sequential pipeline processing
Implement robust error handling and fault tolerance strategies with auto-recovery mechanisms to ensure swarm reliability during long-running operations
Use memory namespaces and persistence to organize agent state, enable cross-session communication, and create checkpoints for complex workflows
anti_patterns: Avoid creating too many agents for simple tasks as coordination overhead can exceed the benefits of parallelization
Do not use parallel execution for tasks with complex dependencies as this leads to race conditions and inconsistent results
Never skip monitoring and health checks for production swarms as silent failures can cascade and cause difficult-to-debug issues

faq.question: What is the difference between swarm topologies?
faq.answer: Mesh topology enables peer-to-peer agent communication for flexible collaboration. Hierarchical has a coordinator agent directing subordinates for structured workflows. Star topology has central coordination with parallel agent execution. Ring topology creates sequential processing chains.

faq.question: How do I install Claude Flow MCP tools?
faq.answer: Install Claude Flow globally with npm install -g claude-flow@alpha, then add the MCP server using claude mcp add claude-flow npx claude-flow@alpha mcp start. Verify installation by checking available MCP tools in Claude Code.

faq.question: Can I use this skill without MCP tools installed?
faq.answer: The skill provides CLI fallback commands using npx claude-flow that work without MCP server configuration. However, MCP tools provide better integration and more advanced features for swarm orchestration.

faq.question: How many agents should I use for a typical workflow?
faq.answer: Start with 3 to 6 agents for most workflows. Research swarms work well with 4 to 6 agents. Development teams typically need 6 to 8 agents. Testing swarms can use 5 to 7 agents. Scale up only if parallelization benefits exceed coordination overhead.

faq.question: How does memory persistence work across swarm sessions?
faq.answer: Use memory_persist tool to enable cross-session state. Organize data with namespaces for different swarms. Set appropriate TTL values for temporary data. Create regular backups and state snapshots for important checkpoints.

faq.question: What happens if an agent fails during execution?
faq.answer: Enable fault tolerance with daa_fault_tolerance tool for auto-recovery. Monitor swarm health with swarm_status. Analyze errors with error_analysis tool. Implement retry logic for critical operations. Use state snapshots to recover from failures.
